Chapter 7: Cryptocurrency

2
CONTENTS
7.1 Introduction
7.2 History and evolution of Digital currency
7.3 Digital currency

Introduction3
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h67mJsPgcrQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h67mJsPgcrQ

History and evolution of Digital currencies5
Stage 1: Idea formation (1995 –1998)
•In 1995, an American cryptologist called David Chaum implemented 
an anonymous form of cryptocurrency called Digicash.
•Bit Gold, commonly known as the forerunner of Bitcoin, was 
designed in 1998 by Nick Szabo. It requires participants to provide 
computing power to solve cryptographic problems, and the solvers 
receive rewards.

History and evolution of Digital currencies6
Stage 2: The beginning (2008 –2010)
•October 31, 2008, Satoshi Nakamoto –published a whitepaper about the 
Bitcoin, a peer -to-peer system of digital currency
•Satoshi Nakamoto “dug” the first block of the Bitcoin network on January 3, 
2009.
•In May 2010, the most expensive pizza in history was bought with 10.000 
Bitcoin, and till the beginning of November, the value of Bitcoin increased to 36 
before stabilizing at 29 cents.

History and evolution of Digital currencies7
Stage 3: The formation of the market (2010 –2013)
•Bitcoin showed that its value could increase rapidly
•Othercryptocurrencies were established: Litecoin, Namecoin , and Swiftcoin , 
pressuring the market.
•Another cryptocurrency called Ripple was established and funded by 
adventurous investors
•In Vancouver in Canada, by contrast, the first automatic teller machine (ATM) 
with Bitcoin was installed.

History and evolution of Digital currencies8
Stage 4: A boom in fraud (2014 –2015)
•In January 2014, Mt.Gox , the largest Bitcoin exchange at the time collapsed 
and had to declare bankruptcy, causing 850,000 Bitcoin losses to investors.
•In 2015, a security flaw caused the Bitstamp exchange in Europe to be hacked

History and evolution of Digital currencies9
Stage 5: Cryptocurrency becomes a phenomenon and a global 
trend (2016 –2020)
•In 2016, cryptocurrencies continued to become a mainstream in the financial 
technology sector. The number of ATMs to withdraw cash from Bitcoin 
increased from 500 to a little fewer than 900 in just one year.
•The price of Bitcoin at this time was also increasing every year, from $434 at the 
beginning of 2016 to $998 in January 2017

Digital currency10
Digital currency is any 
currency that’s available 
exclusively in electronic 
form ( Forbes, 2024)

Digital currency11
1.Digital money is not a tangible asset like cash or commodities.
2.Digital money streamlines financial infrastructure, making it 
cheaper and faster to conduct monetary transactions. 
3.It can also make it easier for central banks to implement 
monetary policy.

Advantages of Digital currency12
•Fast Transfer and Transaction Times
•No Physical Manufacturing Required
•Monetary and Fiscal Policy Implementation
•Cheaper Transaction Costs
•Decentralized
•Privacy
•Accessible Around the World

DisAdvantages of Digital currency13
•Storage and Infrastructure Issues
•Can be difficult to store and use.
•Can be hacked.
•Can have volatile prices that result in lost value.
•May not allow for irrevocability of transactions.
•Still has limited acceptability.

Digital currency types15
There are four main types of digital currency:
•Cryptocurrencies
•Central Bank Digital Currency CBDCs
•Virtual Currencies
•Stablecoins.

Cryto currency16
•Cryptocurrency –is a subset of digital currencies, however, it uses 
cryptography for security so this makes it extremely difficult to 
counterfeit (Gilpin, 2014 ).
•Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies that use cryptography to 
secure and verify transactions in a network.
•Cryptocurrencies are considered virtual currencies because they are 
unregulated and exist only in digital form.

Virtual currency17
•Virtual Currency –in 2012 the European Central Bank defined a 
virtual currency as "a type of unregulated, digital money, which is 
issued and usually controlled by its developers, and used and 
accepted among the members of a specific virtual community.“
•

CBDCs18
•CBDCs are regulated digital currencies issued by the central bank of a 
country
•China: Since 2020, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) has been testing the 
digital yuan , also known as e -CNY, in a number of Chinese localities. Millions 
of Chinese citizens currently utilize the digital yuan, which is intended to be 
used for retail transactions.
•Sweden: Also since 2020, Sweden's Riksbank has been testing the e -krona 
digital currency.

Stablecoins22
•Stablecoins are more useful than 
volatile cryptocurrencies as a 
medium of exchange.
•Stablecoins may be pegged to a 
currency like the U.S. dollar or 
the price of a commodity such as 
gold.

Cryptocurrencies23
•Cryptocurrencies are digital currencies that use cryptography to secure and 
verify transactions in a network.
•Cryptocurrencies are considered virtual currencies because they are 
unregulated and exist only in digital form.
Revenue in the Cryptocurrencies market
Source: https://www.statista.com/outlook/fmo/digital -assets/cryptocurrencies/worldwide

Cryptocurrencies24
•Units of cryptocurrency are created through a process called mining, which 
involves using computer power to solve complicated mathematical problems 
that generate coins.
•Users can also buy the currencies from brokers, then store and spend them 
using cryptographic wallets.

Cryptocurrency examples
•Bitcoin:
➢Founded in 2009, Bitcoin was the first cryptocurrency and is still 
the most commonly traded .
➢The currency was developed by Satoshi Nakamoto25

Cryptocurrency examples
•Ethereum:
➢Developed in 2015, Ethereum is a blockchain platform with its 
own cryptocurrency, called Ether (ETH) or Ethereum.
➢It is the most popular cryptocurrency after Bitcoin.26

Cryptocurrency examples
•Litecoin:
This currency is most similar to bitcoin but has moved more quickly to develop new innovations, 
including faster payments and processes to allow more transactions.
•Ripple:
Ripple is a distributed ledger system that was founded in 2012.
Ripple can be used to track different kinds of transactions, not just cryptocurrency. The 
company behind it has worked with various banks and financial institutions.27

Bitcoin30
Price of Bitcoin in 2024
Source: https://www.binance.com/vi/price/bitcoin

Bitcoin
•Bitcoin is the largest cryptocurrency ever created and traded using a 
decentralized ledger known as the blockchain
•Bitcoin is a network in which every computing node is responsible to service 
the others and allows shared access to the data, known peer to peer (P2P) 
network
•Bitcoin provides an adaption of electronic cash that supports e -payments.31

Bitcoin
•Satoshi Nakamoto introduced bitcoin in 2009 and since then it has emerged as the 
most thriving cryptocurrency
•Bitcoin is a globally accepted and immutable e payment system of digital currency.
•All the electronic transactions performed using bitcoin are verified by the 
intermediate nodes called miners and then added as a block in the distributed 
ledger.
•Bitcoin blockchains are maintained by the miners running Bitcoin software.32

Blockchain technology
•Blockchain is a tamper -proof, distributed and 
decentralized peer -to-peer technology that could track 
and verify digital transactions. 
•Blockchain Technology is a distributed, decentralized, 
peer-peer network to store transactions of the network 
without any third party36

Blockchain technology
•It aims to bring in transparency, security and integrity of 
data.
•This most trusted, decentralized ledger finds it application 
in almost all the domains varying from finance, education, 
energy, supply chain, health care and many more.37

Blockchain Architecture
•Nodes:
Computers or devices participating in the blockchain network.
Each node maintains a copy of the entire blockchain ledger.
•Blocks
Data batches containing multiple transactions.
Each block is cryptographically linked to the previous block, forming a 
chain. 38

Blockchain Architecture
•Transactions
Records of exchanges or interactions between participants.
Transactions are grouped into blocks and validated by network nodes.
•Consensus Mechanism
Rules or protocols that ensure all nodes agree on the state of the 
blockchain.
Examples include Proof of Work ( PoW ), Proof of Stake ( PoS), etc.39

Key Characteristic of Blockchain Technology
•Decent ralization:
Distributed ledger across a network of nodes
No central authority or single point of control•Immutability
Data recorded on the blockchain cannot be altered
Achieved through cryptographic hashing and consensus mechanisms•Smart Contracts
Self-executing contracts with predefined rules and conditions
Automatically enforce agreements without intermediaries•Peer -to-Peer Network
Transactions verified and validated by network nodes
Eliminates intermediaries and reduces transaction costs•Consensus mechanisms 
Ensure all nodes agree on the current state of the blockchain.
Essential for validating transactions and maintaining integrity without central authority42
Blockchain technology44
